text.p: Here are highlights of stories reported by Hungary's press, based on information by Nepszabadsag's Hungary Around the Clock service. For further details on how to subscribe to Hungary Around the Clock, please contact Monica Kovacs at (361) 351 2440 or fax your request to (361) 351 7141.
ALL PAPERS
- Parliament gave permission Tuesday for nearly 300 NATO fighter planes to fly over Hungarian territory on their way to a military exercise in the Mediterranean.
- King Albert of Belgium received President Arpad Goncz. Finance Minister Peter Medgyessy delivered a lecture on the state of the Hungarian economy to more than 100 Belgian businessmen in Brussels.
- Prime Minister Gyula Horn sent letters Tuesday to heads of state and government in neighbouring states informing them of the conclusion of the Hungarian-Romanian basic treaty.
- Foreign Minister Laszlo Kovacs met his Finnish counterpart Tarja Halonen in Budapest on Tuesday.
- The Slovak Parliament ruled Tuesday that from October 1, the national anthem of a foreign state can only be played in Slovakia when a delegation from the given foreign country is present.
- The nuclear power plant Paksi Atomeromu and the German firm Siemens AG signed a DM40 million contract yesterday on modernising the four reactors of the plant.

- Dr. Peter Feldmajer, president of the Federation of Hungarian Jewish Communities, has said about $320 million of the $4 billion Nazi assets kept in Swiss bank accounts might have originated from Hungary.
NEPSZABADSAG
- Foreign Minister Laszlo Kovacs and his Slovak counterpart Pavol Hamzik will meet today.
MAGYAR HIRLAP
- If domestic demand decreases further, economic stagnation will be difficult to stop, warned Andras Koves, deputy managing director of economic analysts Kopint-Datorg in an interview.
- Exports and imports increased by 30.3 percent and 24.3 percent respectively at current prices between January and July 1996, says a Central Statistical Office report.
- Some 5.3 million tonnes of grain were harvested in the country, 18.7 per cent less than in 1995 and over 30 per cent below the average over the years 1986-1990.

- The electronics giant Philips plans to invest $50 million in Hungary by late next year and increase the number of its employees by 1,500 to over 5,500, announced Willem J. van der Vegt, president and CEO of Philips Hungary.
- Environmental factors are instrumental in the death of every fourth person in Hungary and the mortality rates of both adult males and females are higher than the European average.
NAPI GAZDASAG
- Water charges will rise in accordance with inflation next year, according to the Ministry of Transport, Telecommunications and Water Management.
- The insurance company Hungaria Biztosito plans to become the third largest firm of its kind in terms of life insurance, and to enter the market in health and credit insurance.
- The fourth attempt to privatise the foodstuffs retail company Balaton Fuszert will take place in October.
- A new international port is to be built on the Danube near Gyor by year 2010, Transport Minister Karoly Lotz said yesterday at a meeting of a UN European Economic Committee group in Budapest.
VILAGGAZDASAG

- A senior labour official confirmed Tuesday that a fine of about 6-7 million forints would be imposed on employers who took on foreigners without work permits at the construction site of the Duna Plaza shopping centre last Thursday.
